Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
• Bright orange to reddish-orange body, very striking in the water.
• A thick white vertical bar behind the head — the most defining feature.
• Box-shaped, rigid body (carapace) typical of Aracanidae boxfishes.
• Small, rounded fins that flick rapidly for slow, hovering movement.
• Blunt snout with small mouth; eyes set high on the head.
• Tail is short and rounded, often slightly translucent.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
• Endemic to southern Australia, especially common in Western Australia.
• Seen frequently around:
    ◦ Rottnest Island
    ◦ Perth metro reefs
    ◦ Geographe Bay
    ◦ South coast and Great Australian Bight
• Found on:
    ◦ rocky reefs
    ◦ sponge gardens
    ◦ deep ledges
    ◦ mixed kelp areas
• Depth range: 5–120 m

(Shallower around Rottnest; deeper individuals found further offshore.)
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Swimming style
• Slow swimmers — they hover using pectoral and dorsal fin flicks.
• Their rigid body doesn’t bend, unlike leatherjackets or wrasses.
Defence & toxins
• When stressed, boxfishes can release ostracitoxin, a potent skin toxin that deters predators.
• (They don’t pose danger to divers unless handled.)
Diet
Feeds mainly on:
• sponges
• small crustaceans
• worms
• benthic invertebrates
• occasionally algae
Social behaviour
• Usually solitary.
• Occasionally seen in loose pairs or small groups around reef edges.
📏 Size
• Common size: 18–25 cm
• Maximum: ~30 cm
🧬 Sexual Differences
Unlike many wrasses or leatherjackets, males and females look quite similar.

Juveniles show multiple white bands, which reduce to the classic single white bar in adults.
🤿 Notes for Divers
• Very approachable, slow-moving, and easy to photograph.
• Often found near caves, overhangs, and sponge patches.
• May turn sideways and freeze when approached — a defensive behaviour.
• Because their body is rigid, sudden turns are slow and predictable.
🧠 Fun & Useful Fact
Boxfishes (family Aracanidae) are incredibly hydrodynamically efficient: engineers have studied their boxy body shape because it allows stable, low-energy hovering — inspiring underwater drone designs.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Discuss boxfish toxins, reef defensive adaptations, and sexual dimorphism in reef fishes.
Region Found: Great Australian Bight (WA–SA), Perth offshore reefs, Rottnest Island, Southwest shelf

Dive Site Areas: Rottnest Island, Perth offshore reefs, Busselton Jetty region, Albany reefs, Esperance archipelago
Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
• One of WA’s most distinctive boxfishes due to its pattern of pale spots or lines arranged in rings or swirls (“aurita” means ear-shaped patterns).
• Males typically show stronger blue or pale markings; females and juveniles are more brown-orange.
• Rigid, armour-like carapace of fused bony plates — the body cannot bend.
• Fins are small and rounded, producing a slow hovering movement.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
• Common around Rottnest, Perth, Bunbury, Busselton, south coast reefs, Esperance, and eastwards into SA.
• Prefers:

    ◦ rocky reef
    ◦ kelp edges
    ◦ sponge gardens
    ◦ seagrass margins
• Depth: 10–100 m, usually deeper than Whitebarred Boxfish.
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Swimming & movement
• Slow, stable swimmers using small side-fins and dorsal fin pulses — extremely hydrodynamically efficient.
• Cannot turn quickly due to their rigid body; relies on fin control rather than body flexing.
Defence
• Protected by a highly developed, enclosed carapace (more reinforced than the typical Indo-Pacific boxfish).
• When threatened, may release toxins (ostracitoxin) into the water, like most boxfish.
Diet
• Omnivorous grazer feeding on:

    ◦ sponges
    ◦ small benthic crustaceans
    ◦ worms
    ◦ ascidians
    ◦ soft algae
• Bites are precise due to their small, beak-like mouth.
Sexual dimorphism
• Males often have brighter, more contrasting patterns.
• Females and juveniles are browner, with muted markings.
• Pattern can vary regionally.
Social behaviour
• Mostly solitary, occasionally in pairs.
• Moves calmly around reef edges and slopes.
📏 Size
• Common size: 12–18 cm
• Max size: 20–22 cm
🤿 Notes for Divers
• A very calm and approachable species.
• Often seen near sponge outcrops or low caves on deeper dives.
• Due to slow swimming, easy to photograph — but avoid hovering too close as prolonged stress increases toxin risk.
🧠 High-Value Learning Concepts
(Useful for Ocean Planet educational features)
1. Boxfish Hydrodynamics
Shaw’s Boxfish demonstrates how a “boxy” shape can still be extremely stable, inspiring underwater drone and robotics designs.
2. Evolution of Carapace Armour
Aracana species showcase the evolutionary transition from flexible-bodied reef fish toward fully plated, rigid defence systems.
3. Toxin Defence Mechanisms
Understanding how and why boxfish release toxins highlights reef chemical ecology and predator-prey coevolution.
4. Sexual Dimorphism & Patterning
Subtle male-female differences can teach divers about visual signalling and mating strategies in slow-moving species.
5. Endemic Species Awareness
Shaw’s Boxfish is a southern Australian endemic, making it a great ambassador species for discussions on WA biodiversity and local conservation.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Explain boxfish evolution, toxin defence, hydrodynamic stability, and compare Shaw’s Boxfish with Whitebarred Boxfish to teach camouflage, patterning, and habitat preferences.
Region Found: Great Australian Bight, South Coast Bioregion, South-west WA, Southern Australia, West Coast Bioregion

Dive Site Areas: Rottnest Island deep ledges, Perth offshore reefs (e.g., Three-Mile Reef slopes), Naturaliste Plateau margins, Albany & Esperance reef walls
Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
• Long, slender, almost lizardfish-shaped body.
• Red to pink body with mottled darker patches and pale belly.
• Distinctive bright red dorsal spines.
• Large, fan-shaped pectoral fins used for sudden bursts of movement.
• Eyes set toward the top of the head — an ambush predator feature.
• Tail slightly forked, streamlined for fast acceleration along the bottom.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
• Found across southern Australia, including WA, SA, NSW, VIC, and TAS.
• In WA, commonly seen around:
    ◦ Rottnest Island (deeper ledges)
    ◦ Perth offshore reefs
    ◦ Naturaliste & south-west reef slopes
    ◦ Albany and Esperance
• Prefers:
    ◦ sand–rock interfaces
    ◦ deep ledges and caves
    ◦ sponge gardens
    ◦ lower reef slopes
• Depth: 20–250 m, most abundant 40–100 m.

(In your photo, the cave-overhang + rubble bottom is textbook habitat.)
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Ambush predator
• Uses camouflage to blend with sand and rubble.
• Feeds on:
    ◦ small fishes
    ◦ crustaceans
    ◦ cephalopods
    ◦ benthic invertebrates
• Usually lies still on the bottom, then lunges rapidly at passing prey.
Activity
• Often solitary.
• Prefers low-light areas: deep reefs, caves, and overhangs.
• Moves only when approached too close, then darts quickly.
🧬 Morphology & Adaptations
• Belongs to Aulopiformes, a group including lizardfishes and tripodfishes.
• Streamlined shape allows sudden bursts of speed from complete stillness.
• Camouflage pattern helps avoid predators and hide from prey.
• Strong pectoral muscles for quick directional shifts.
📏 Size
• Common: 30–45 cm
• Maximum: ~60 cm
🤿 Notes for Divers
• Usually encountered motionless on cave floors or ledges.
• Despite the striking red coloration underwater, they blend incredibly well into rubble and sponge-covered reefs.
• Approach slowly; they tend to dart away in a straight, fast burst.
• Great species for teaching students about deep-reef adaptations and ambush feeding strategies.
🧠 High-Value Learning Concepts
(perfect for mini-lessons)
1. Ambush Predation & Camouflage

Sergeant Baker is an excellent example of how morphology, colour pattern, and behaviour come together to create an effective bottom predator.
2. Deep Reef Ecology

Their presence highlights the importance of mid-depth and deeper ledge habitats, often overlooked in marine education.
3. Evolutionary Position

As part of the Aulopiformes, they show transitional traits between fast-swimming open-water predators and cryptic benthic ambushers.
4. Benthic Predator Role

Helps maintain ecological balance by controlling populations of small reef fishes and crustaceans.
5. Adaptation to Low Light

Large eyes and still-hunting behaviour illustrate how animals adapt to the dim environments of deeper reefs and caves.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Use to teach ambush predation, deep reef habitat adaptations, camouflage strategies, and ecological roles of demersal predators.
Region Found: Great Australian Bight, South Coast Bioregion, Southern Australia east to NSW and Tasmania, West Coast Bioregion

Dive Site Areas: Rottnest Island (Little Salmon Bay, Parker Point, Sloping Reef), Marmion Marine Park, Busselton Jetty, Coral Bay, Ningaloo Reef
Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
• One of WA’s most striking sea slugs.
• Mantle shows three key colour zones:
    ◦ Bright orange border
    ◦ Blue-white outer band
    ◦ Black central band
• Rhinophores and gill plume are orange to red-orange.
• Smooth, glossy mantle with no raised tubercles.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
• Endemic to Western Australia, found from Perth → Rottnest → Coral Bay → Ningaloo.
• Lives on:
    ◦ shallow reef tops
    ◦ sponge gardens
    ◦ rocky ledges
    ◦ coral rubble
• Depth: 3–30 m
Often seen crawling on sponges — their primary food source.
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Diet
Feeds exclusively on specific sponges.

The bright colours advertise toxicity acquired from sponge chemicals.
Defence
• Bright colours = aposematic signalling
• Stores toxic compounds from its prey and becomes unpalatable to predators.
Movement
• Slow crawler
• Uses chemo-sensing to track sponge trails
• Often seen in pairs or following scent trails during mating seasons
📏 Size
• Typical length: 25–40 mm
• Large individuals: 50–60 mm
🤿 Notes for Divers
• Very photogenic and slow-moving
• Often overlooked due to small size but extremely common around Rottnest
• Found under ledges, sponge patches, and near cave entrances
• Flash photography reveals the electric blue mantle beautifully
🧠 High-Value Learning Concepts
Perfect for Ocean Planet micro-lessons:
1. Aposematism (warning coloration)

Nudibranchs use bright colours as a survival strategy — opposite of camouflage.
2. Specialised feeding
C. westraliensis demonstrates extreme dietary specialisation, feeding on only a few sponge genera.
3. Chemical ecology

Highlights how reef animals use toxins from their food for defence.
4. Endemic biodiversity

A charismatic example of WA’s unique marine life.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Teach nudibranch anatomy, colour-based defence strategies, sponge–nudibranch ecological interactions, and WA endemism.
Region Found: Gascoyne Coast Bioregion, Ningaloo, Rottnest Island, South-west WA, Southern WA reefs, West Coast Bioregion
Tags: benthic, colourful, endemic (WA region), nudibranch, reef

Dive Site Areas: Rottnest Island bays & bommies, Perth offshore reefs, Busselton Jetty, Dunsborough, Albany, Esperance
Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
• Small to medium trevally with slender, streamlined body.
• Silvery colour with blue–green tinge along the upper body.
• Often shows a faint dark shoulder spot near the pectoral fin.
• Forked tail built for speed.
• Dorsal and anal fins sometimes edged with pale yellow.
• Skipjack Trevally are smaller and slimmer than Silver Trevally.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
• Occurs along the entire southern half of Australia, including all of WA’s temperate coastlines.
• Common around:
    ◦ Rottnest Island
    ◦ Perth nearshore & offshore reefs
    ◦ Busselton Jetty
    ◦ Albany & Esperance
• Habitat:
    ◦ inshore reefs
    ◦ sandy channels
    ◦ kelp edges
    ◦ harbours & jetties
    ◦ open water over reefs
• Depth: 2–80 m
Often seen in small schools cruising mid-water above reef platforms.
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Feeding
Carnivorous, feeding on:
• small baitfish
• prawns
• zooplankton
• squid
• small crustaceans in mid-water
Their speed and schooling behaviour help them overwhelm prey.
Schooling
• Usually found in tight, fast-moving schools.
• Juveniles form large shoals; adults often in small groups.
• Mixed schools with other trevallies and hardyheads are common.
Movement
• Highly mobile species.
• Patrols reef edges and sand channels looking for prey.
• Often circle divers as they pass — very curious fish.
🧬 Adaptations
• Deeply forked caudal fin for high acceleration.
• Large eyes — excellent visual predators in clear water.
• Compressed body reduces drag, improving energy efficiency.
📏 Size
• Common: 20–30 cm
• Maximum: 40+ cm
(Larger individuals are often mistaken for juvenile Silver Trevallies.)
🤿 Notes for Divers
• Often the first fish to appear when entering the water on a WA dive.
• Circle divers curiously, then dart away.
• Great for practising fish ID and observing mid-water feeding behaviour.
• Schools create beautiful photo opportunities when backlit in clear blue water.
🧠 High-Value Learning Concepts
1. Schooling as a Survival Strategy

Skipjack Trevallies demonstrate how coordinated group movement reduces predation risk and improves foraging efficiency.
2. Hydrodynamics of Fast-Swimming Fish

Their shape and tail design illustrate principles of speed, thrust, and turning in pelagic species.
3. Trophic Dynamics

They occupy an important mid-level predator role, linking planktonic prey to larger reef predators.
4. Species Confusion & ID Skills

Helps divers learn differences between Skipjack Trevally, Silver Trevally, and juvenile Giant Trevally.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Teach hydrodynamics, schooling behaviour, food web connections, and identification of similar trevally species.
Region Found: Esperance, Perth Metro reefs, Rottnest Island, South Coast Bioregion, South-west WA, Southern Australian coast, West Coast Bioregion
Seasonal Occurrence: Year-round (schools often more abundant in warmer months)

Dive Site Areas: Rottnest Island (Little Salmon Bay, Crystal Palace, Parker Point), Marmion Marine Park, Busselton Jetty, Albany, Esperance
Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
• Deep-bodied, oval-shaped fish with bold black vertical bars (usually 5–6).
• Body colour ranges from silver-white to golden, depending on age and lighting.
• Fins often yellowish or translucent.
• Snout is short and rounded.
• The black tail band is distinctive, with a pale central patch.
• Juveniles often show brighter, more contrasting stripes.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
• Endemic to southern Australia, especially abundant in WA near Rottnest, Perth, Bunbury, Albany, and Esperance.
• Found around:
    ◦ limestone reef
    ◦ kelp beds (especially Ecklonia forests)
    ◦ rocky walls and overhangs
    ◦ protected coves
• Depth range: 3–70 m
• Juveniles commonly found in shallow surge channels and sheltered bays.
Moonlighters prefer complex habitat where they can dart into crevices when disturbed.
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Feeding
Omnivorous benthic feeders:
• small crustaceans
• polychaete worms
• bryozoans
• algae
• sponge-associated fauna
Their varied diet reflects their adaptability to different reef environments.
Activity
• Typically solitary or seen in pairs.
• Juveniles may form small groups in shallow kelp beds.
• Extremely site-attached — individuals often stay on the same reef section for months or years.
Predator avoidance
• Darting escape behaviour, using caves and kelp thickets for cover.
• Bars provide disruptive camouflage, breaking up the body outline.
🧬 Adaptations
• Deep, compressed body suited to maneuvering through complex reef.
• Strong pectoral fins enable rapid pivots when threatened.
• Vertical stripes reduce silhouette visibility in kelp shadows — excellent camouflage.
• Teeth adapted for scraping and picking benthic prey.
📏 Size
• Common: 20–30 cm
• Maximum: 45 cm
Moonlighters grow larger than many divers expect, especially in deeper reefs.
🤿 Notes for Divers
• A common but often overlooked species around Rottnest and Perth reefs.
• Shy — usually turns away when approached, showing its striped profile.
• Excellent fish for teaching beginners colour pattern recognition and reef fish behaviour.
• Often spotted near ledges where dhufish and breaksea cod hide, making them a useful “indicator species” of productive reef structure.
🧠 High-Value Learning Concepts
Perfect for Ocean Planet micro-lessons:
1. Endemism in Southern Australia

Moonlighters help highlight WA’s unique temperate reef biodiversity.
2. Disruptive Colouration & Camouflage

Their stripes demonstrate how animals break up their visual outline to confuse predators.
3. Reef Habitat Complexity

Shows how kelp, ledges, and caves support species that rely on structure for protection.
4. Ontogenetic Habitat Shifts

Juveniles and adults use slightly different habitats — a good teaching point for fish life cycles.
5. Ecological Role

As omnivores, Moonlighters link benthic invertebrate communities with higher predators.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Teach camouflage, endemism, reef habitat structure, and comparisons between Moonlighters and similar striped species (e.g., Western Striped Trumpeter, Stripey).
Region Found: Albany, Esperance, Perth Metro reefs, Rottnest Island, South Coast Bioregion, West Coast Bioregion

Dive Site Areas: Rottnest Island (Crystal Palace, West End, Fish Hook Bay), Perth offshore reefs, Busselton Jetty, Dunsborough, Albany, Esperance
Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
• Small, distinctive bullhead shark with a blunt head and ridge-like “horns” over the eyes.
• Beige to light brown body with dark harness-like bands across the head and body — the key ID feature.
• Spiracles just behind the eyes, typical of bottom-dwelling sharks.
• Two dorsal fins each armed with a sharp, upright spine.
• Tail (caudal fin) asymmetrical but rounded.
Port Jackson Sharks are extremely easy to identify once you recognise the harness banding.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
• Found throughout southern Australia, but in WA they are especially abundant around Rottnest, the Perth coastline, and the south coast.
• Prefers:
    ◦ rocky reef
    ◦ caves and ledges
    ◦ sandy gutters near reef
    ◦ sponge gardens
• Depth: 0–275 m
• Commonly seen by divers resting in caves or cruising slowly along the bottom at night.
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Feeding
Crush-feeding specialists, eating:
• sea urchins
• molluscs
• crustaceans
• tube worms
• occasionally small fish
Their strong, flattened molar-like teeth allow them to break hard shells easily.
Movement
• Slow-moving, energy-efficient benthic shark.
• Often rests on the bottom, especially during the day.
• Nocturnal hunters — far more active at night.
Reproduction
• Oviparous (egg-laying).
• Females deposit spiral-shaped egg capsules known as “mermaid’s purses”.
• Eggs are wedged into rock crevices to prevent predators from removing them.
• One of the most iconic shark breeding strategies in Australian waters.
Social behaviour
• Known to form seasonal aggregations, sometimes with dozens resting together.
• Generally docile and tolerant of divers.
🧬 Adaptations
• Large spiracles allow bottom-breathing while stationary.
• Dorsal spines provide protection against larger predators.
• Harness pattern serves as disruptive camouflage among rocks and kelp shadows.
• Very strong jaw plates evolved for durophagy (crushing hard-shelled prey).
• Eggs shaped like a helicopter drill bit so they can be screwed into crevices — extremely clever evolutionary design.
📏 Size
• Common adult length: 75–95 cm
• Maximum: 120–130 cm
🤿 Notes for Divers
• One of the most relaxed and diver-friendly sharks in WA.
• Often found in caves, under boulders, or resting on sand near reef.
• Generally unbothered by bubbles — divers can observe them at close range without stress.
• Excellent species for teaching shark biology to beginners because they demonstrate so many unique features (egg-laying, dorsal spines, spiracles, slow swimming).
🧠 High-Value Learning Concepts
Perfect for Ocean Planet mini-lessons:
1. Shark Diversity

Demonstrates how different shark species can be from the “classic” fast-swimming pelagic sharks.
2. Oviparity & Egg Capsules

Port Jackson Sharks are a leading example of spiral egg-case evolution and benthic reproductive strategies.
3. Durophagy (Shell-Crushing Feeding)

Evolution of specialised teeth and jaws to exploit hard-shelled prey.
4. Low-Energy Lifestyle

Shows how sharks adapt to low productivity environments by reducing energy expenditure.
5. Misconceptions About Sharks

A friendly, non-threatening species that helps teach the public that most sharks are not dangerous.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Teach shark diversity, egg-laying strategies, durophagy, benthic ecology, and use them to challenge misconceptions about sharks being universally dangerous or aggressive.
Region Found: Busselton, Perth, Rottnest Island, South Coast Bioregion, West Coast Bioregion
Seasonal Occurrence: Year-round (peak sightings in winter–spring when egg-laying increases)

Dive Site Areas: Rottnest Island (Parker Point, Crystal Palace, West End), Perth metro reefs, Busselton Jetty, Albany, Esperance
Key Facts & Learning:
🔍 Identification
The Southern Maori Wrasse is one of WA’s most visually striking wrasses:
• Large wrasse with a deep body and thick lips
• Distinct white, grey, brown, or olive base colour depending on age
• Decorated with fine blue lines and scribbles on the face (classic “Maori” pattern)
• Dark vertical bars sometimes present on juveniles
• Long, pointed pectoral fins
• Larger individuals may show bronze, turquoise, or lavender tones
Sex & Age Differences
• Females / juveniles: Smaller, mottled brown or green with faint spots or bars.
• Terminal-phase males: Larger, more colourful, and boldly patterned — blue scribbles strongest around the head.
🌊 Distribution & Habitat
Occurs widely across southern temperate Australia, and is common around Rottnest and Perth.
Habitats:
• Kelp forests (Ecklonia radiata)
• Rocky reefs
• Limestone ledges
• Sand-reef interfaces
• Caves and gutters
Depth: 2–60 m

(You’ll see juveniles in the shallows; adults often patrol deeper reef structure.)
A very common and charismatic species for WA recreational divers.
🐠 Behaviour & Ecology
Feeding
A benthic carnivore feeding on:
• molluscs
• crabs
• sea urchins
• tube worms
• small crustaceans
Uses strong jaws and teeth to crush shells — a shared trait among many large wrasses.
Social System
Southern Maori Wrasse are protogynous sequential hermaphrodites, meaning:
• All begin life as females
• Some transition to males as they grow and when social conditions require it
Terminal males often hold small territories and patrol reef edges.
Activity & Behaviour
• Diurnal (active during the day)
• Curious but cautious around divers
• Often approach divers if foraging in the area
• At night, they wedge into caves or rest on sand patches
Their strong pectoral swimming style (typical of wrasses) makes them maneuverable around reef structure.
🧬 Adaptations
• Crushing dentition ideal for eating hard-shelled prey
• Bright facial markings used for communication between individuals
• Protogyny allows the species to maintain balanced sex ratios
• Large eyes adapted for hunting in complex rocky reef shadows
📏 Size
• Common adult length: 30–50 cm
• Maximum size: ~60 cm
• Males grow significantly larger than females
🤿 Notes for Divers
• Very common around Rottnest and a favourite among photographers
• Often seen tailing other species (e.g., goatfish or rays) to steal exposed prey
• Larger males may briefly inspect divers before veering away
• A great species for teaching beginners about colour patterns and wrasse behaviour
🧠 High-Value Learning Concepts
Ideal for Ocean Planet micro-lessons:
1. Sequential Hermaphroditism (Protogyny)

Demonstrates complex social biology and flexibility in fish reproductive roles.
2. Wrasse Feeding Adaptations

Jaw strength and dentition highlight the ecological importance of wrasses as predators of hard-shelled invertebrates.
3. Temperate Reef Ecology

Southern Maori Wrasse are excellent ambassadors for WA’s kelp-dominated reefs.
4. Facial Patterning

Shows how colour and pattern can signal social status and facilitate species recognition.
5. Indicator Species

Presence of large wrasses often indicates a healthy reef with abundant invertebrate prey.
Mini Lesson Recommendations: Teach protogyny, wrasse feeding strategies, reef food-web roles, and facial pattern communication in temperate reef fishes.
Region Found: Albany, Busselton, Dunsborough, Esperance, Perth Metro reefs, Rottnest Island, South Coast Bioregion, Southern Australia, West Coast Bioregion
Tags: Wrasse, bold pattern, carnivore, protogynous, reef
